title: 500kg Egyptian woman arrives in India for lifesaving treatment
text:
500kg Egyptian woman arrives in India for lifesaving treatment Last updated 19:57, February 14 2017 
An Egyptian woman with a medical condition which caused her to balloon to 500kg has landed in India for potentially lifesaving treatment. 
Eman Ahmed, 36, emerged from her home for the first time in 25 years after being extracted by a crane and put on a cargo aircraft to Mumbai. 
Upon her arrival in India, Ahmed was transferred to a truck to Saifee Hospital, where she has been put on a high-protein liquid diet, the Hindustan Times reported. YouTube 
Eman Ahmed, who weighs 500kg, was flown to India for lifesaving treatment. 
The hospital specially converted a ground-floor accounts office into a 1000sqft facility to house Ahmed, who was accompanied on the journey by two doctors. 
She will undergo a series of stringent medical tests before she can be cleared for surgery. GETTY IMAGES 
A special crane was used by the hospital to carry her bed inside a room catered to her treatment needs. 
Ahmed was born weighing 5kg and diagnosed with elephantiasis, a condition in which body parts swell due to a parasitic infection, a medical website reported. 
Thyroid problems forced her to stop going to school as a child, the Hindustan Times reported. In 2014, when she tipped the scales at 300kg, Ahmed suffered a stroke which left her paralysed, affected her speech and left her bedridden. 
Ahmed will be operated on by veteran bariatric specialist Muffazal Lakdawala, who agreed to help the family pro bono after her desperate sister reached out to him. GETTY IMAGES 
Eman Ahmed arrives at Saifee Hospital, on February 11, 2017 in Mumbai, India. 
Egyptian doctors had said there was little they could do for Ahmed. Ad Feedback 
Lakdawala said when he first saw Ahmed's picture, he was shocked she managed to be alive despite her host of grave medical problems. 
"At the age of 11, Eman had gained immense weight because of which she could not stand up on her own, and would crawl on the knees," Lakdawala told My Medical Mantra last year. GETTY IMAGES 
Eman Ahmed being transported to hospital in a truck. 
He said he was determined to help Eman with his gifts. 
"If I can somehow use whatever God-gifted talent I have to save her, I must try," Lakdawala told The Washington Post . Facebook
